title.narrative: Dushanbe-Kyrgyz Border Road Rehabilitation Project, Phase II (Tajikistan)

description.narrative: The project of L2196-TAJ was approved in 2005, as a government priority. It aims to rehabilitate the road from Dushanbe to the border with the Kyrgyz Republic - part of the CAREC Transport corridors 3 and 5. The supplementary grant will reinforce that project's development impact, outcome and outputs. It will complete the entire Dushanbe-Kyrgyz border road (the road). The supplementary grant original outputs are (i) the rehabilitated road section from Obigarm to Nurobod (km 95-140), (ii) the repaired emergency bypass road at km 110-112, (iii) the improved central section from Nurobod to Nimich (km 140-217) and (iv) the upgraded border section at Karamyk. This grant financing will improve 127-km of the road and 7-km of the bypass road.

title.narrative: Reports and Recommendations of the President

description.narrative: Original project outcome reinforced; improved access to markets and social services.

title.narrative: Reports and Recommendations of the President
By 2012, daily international freight traffic on the project corridor increased to 177 trucks (baseline: 10 trucks in 2006)

description.narrative: Original project outcome reinforced; improved access to markets and social services.

title.narrative: By 2012, travel time between Dushanbe and the Kyrgyz border reduced to 7 hours (baseline: 10 hours in 2006)

description.narrative: Original project outcome reinforced; improved access to markets and social services.

title.narrative: By 2012, domestic traffic on the project corridor increased to 750 AADT (baseline: 250 AADT in 2006)

description.narrative: Original project outcome reinforced; improved access to markets and social services.

title.narrative: By 2012, traffic accidents on the project corridor reduced to 14 accidents per 750 AADT(baseline: 14 accidents per 250 AADT in 2006)

description.narrative: Original project outcome reinforced; improved access to markets and social services.
